TO visitors and customers, Raphael's impressive multimillion-dollar winery and carefully tended 54 acres of vineyards are synonymous with thorough attention to detail. So are Richard Olsen-Harbich's wines.

Raphael's 2004 sauvignon blanc and 2004 rosé, his summer releases, are so sophisticated that a European collector, tasting them blindfolded, might attribute them to the Loire and Provence, respectively.
Both treats from Raphael's Peconic estate are the equivalents not of oil paintings that deliver big statements but of masterly watercolors that tell subdued stories with delicacy.

No surprise. Mr. Olsen-Harbich, who has made wine on Long Island for a quarter-century, is not a devotee of blockbusters. Neither is Raphael's consulting winemaker, Paul Pontallier, the managing director of Château Margaux in Bordeaux.
Raphael shuns chardonnay, and Mr. Olsen-Harbich says that sauvignon blanc is ''the best white grape variety on the North Fork.''

Using grapes reared by the seasoned Benjamin Sisson, Raphael's environmentally oriented vineyard manager, Raphael strives for wines that are prized by consumers whose tastes are guided not by 90-point numerical scores but by classical criteria like balance and grace.
Those values define Raphael's Sancerre-like sauvignon blanc ($20), which is as light as a breeze.

Using a production method that helps German producers heighten rieslings (especially J.J. Prüm in the Mosel), Mr. Olsen-Harbich fermented his sauvignon blanc grape juice at a very low temperature (45 degrees Fahrenheit) and bottled the wine soon after to retain carbon dioxide bubbles.

This spritz, he said, ''keeps the wine extremely fresh and adds to its brightness and liveliness.'' Indeed it does, and, Mr. Olsen-Harbich says, makes his brisk, grapefruity sauvignon blanc the ''perfect wine to complement local seafood.'' He accurately finds gooseberry and kiwi characteristics in this white.

Raphael specializes in merlot, which it uses in its vivid rosé ($16), called Saignée, a French term that means ''bled.'' During grape crushing and before fermentation began, the merlot grape juice was drawn off -- that is, bled -- from the vats, leaving a tincture of pink. The pink juice was then cold-fermented in stainless steel vessels to preserve its fruitiness.

In effect, Saignée is two wines in one. When fully chilled, it is a refreshing rosé with hints of strawberry in the aroma and flavor; in Mr. Olsen-Harbich's view, cherry and guava characteristics are detectable, although I do not pick them up. Mouth-filling and tangy, Saignée is something of a dry confection.

When allowed to warm up in bottle or glass, the wine becomes a light red and seems surprisingly concentrated on the palate. This means that I could first pour it as an aperitif, then put it aside for 20 minutes and return to it as an accompaniment to, say, pasta or light meat dishes. That's versatility.
